chunks.en: As a coder, you all know the level of your peers, right? Dare you entrust the car you're riding in to code control?

I recently saw this programmer's comments on various domestic intelligent driving systems, and I found it quite interesting.

He said that many people are 'bold' and completely trust the intelligent driving system because they don't understand the level of code used in the back-end implementation of intelligent driving in China. Many of them are just patching up some open-source solutions, which insiders know is a 'shit mountain'.

Anyway, he doesn't dare.

I want to ask, are there any programmer friends in the automotive industry? Are you more concerned about the safety of code execution results than ordinary software companies?
The mistake is in doing intelligent driving in China. If it were exclusive to foreign countries, there would be no such concerns.

Safety in any industry is never guaranteed by 'skill level'. Google also has many programmers who are not 'skilled', and even skilled programmers make mistakes. Safety is guaranteed by 'process'. So what I don't trust is the process, not the skill level of a certain programmer.

Subways, high-speed rails, airplanes, amusement parks, elevators - many of these are run by code, so don't ride them. Just find a mangy donkey, ride it every day, hug the donkey's head to work, it's safe and beautiful.

Once you've been driving on the road for a long time, you'll know that the quality, IQ, and driving skills of those demons and monsters on the road are definitely not as good as the code written by my colleagues.
I suggest you see a traditional Chinese medicine doctor when you're sick, that doesn't involve code.

It's just assisted driving, but they insist on marketing intelligent driving and creating an atmosphere of self-driving. Now, things went wrong and those brainless people have risked their lives and fortunes.
The requirements for automotive standards are indeed higher and the testing is more stringent, but I still don't believe it.
Tesla is definitely not a shit mountain, because it's not domestic, so it's worthy of complete trust (ğŸ¶ğŸ¶ğŸ¶ğŸ¶ğŸ¶ğŸ¶ğŸ¶ğŸ¶ğŸ¶ add a bit more)

1. As long as the function can run, the code involving personal safety will be very rigorous. Suspecting personal safety issues is like drinking poison to quench thirst. 2. Regarding code shit mountains, there is no distinction between domestic and foreign. As long as the function is constantly iterated, there is a probability of appearing. Don't be superstitious about foreign countries. Look at GitHub, there are a lot of bad code. The code without shit mountains only appears in personal projects, because there is only one person who can speak.
@x86 Domestic food problems are so serious, but here in the car company, it becomes a white lotus ~~ I suggest you make an appointment to check it out~

@DigitaIOcean #23 I feel that these are less complex than cars. There are too many situations on road sections where cars are driving automatically. In order to take care of various situations, a lot of complex code needs to be written. As we all know, the more complex the problem, the bigger it is. It can only be said that the probability of these problems you mentioned is small, and the probability of car problems is high.

chunks.en: Regarding the few popular posts on V2EX a few days ago about driving on the highway, I am still willing to entrust the car to code full of bugs https://v2ex.com/t/1108942https://v2ex.com/t/1109246
@agagega #7 You mentioned 'process', so I ask, are the program launch 'processes' of these new domestic car manufacturers more standardized than ordinary software companies?

I trust myself the most, but I also have to sit in the passenger seat. Compared to others, I trust the code that has thoroughly understood the road experience of hundreds of thousands of excellent drivers more. So where exactly is the code unsafe?

chunks.en: The coding skills of others have nothing to do with the coding skills of the people around you. If an industry always gives people the impression that 'just like Microsoft can use Electron to write VS Code, can you? You can't, and neither can the people around you, and then you start cursing Electron', you probably already know that you are the frog in the well.

chunks.en: I am a programmer in the automotive industry. In summary, there are many documents, a lot of ut, it, sd, and dd, and a lot of case coverage. However, the shit mountain is a real shit mountain, and it's a headache to modify the code. But consumers don't care about your code quality, so it doesn't matter.
Shit mountains don't prevent the code from running. As long as there are complete test cases, it can still be released.
I have a friend who studies medicine, and I know her capabilities. Does that mean I shouldn't dare to go to the hospital for treatment?

chunks.en: You're all programmers, how could you come to such a ridiculous conclusion? I suggest you stay away from this person. Wait. Isn't this the OP's point of view? You can apply this sentence to any industry. 'As a coder, you all know the level of your peers, right? Dare you entrust your wallet to code control?' In modern engineering, code being a mess doesn't mean it can't run. Even if your code is shitty, 1+1 = 2 won't be wrong. It's just that later people can't refactor it.

The control group for intelligent driving is yourself, and the accident rate of the general public is just a reference. For example, I have been driving safely for more than ten years, and I definitely trust my own abilities more. So I use intelligent driving in crowded areas with low speeds to save energy, and I drive myself in high-speed lanes to ensure safety. A few accidents at low speeds don't matter, it's just a matter of going through insurance and paying money. Handing it over to intelligent driving can save energy and allow me to concentrate on driving in dangerous high-speed areas.
